titleStmt.title: Severall letters from Ireland of the late good success of the Parliament forces there one from Col. Hewson Governour of Dublin, sent to the Honourable William Lenthall Esq; Speaker of the Parliament. VVherein were inclosed the summons, and other passages between him and the governour of the strong garison and fort of Ballisanon. Together vvith the propositions tendred by them, and refused. As also the articles upon which the same was surrendred, dated the first day of March 1649. Two other letters from William Basil Esquire, Atturney Generall for the state in Ireland. March 18. 1649. These letters and papers are appointed to be printed and published. Imprimatur, Henry Scobel. Cler. Parliamenti.;
titleStmt.author: Hewson, John, d. 1662.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 17 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Severall Letters from IRELAND Of the late Good ≈øucce≈øs of the Parliament forces there ONE From Col. Hew≈øon Governour of Dublin, ≈øent to the Honourable William Lenthall E≈øq; Speaker of the PARLIAMENT.
VVherein were inclo≈øed the Summons, and other pa≈ø≈øages between him and the Governour of the ≈øtrong Gari≈øon and Fort of Balli≈øanon.
Together VVith the Propo≈øitions tendred by them, and refu≈øed. As al≈øo the Articles upon which the ≈øame was ≈øurrendred, Dated the Fir≈øt day of March 1649.
TWO Other Letters from William Ba≈øil E≈øquire, Atturney Generall for the State in Ireland.
THe≈øe Letters and Papers are appointed to be Printed and publi≈øhed.
London Printed for Robert Ibbit≈øon in Smithfield near the Queens-head Tavern, 1649.

div.head: To the Honourable William Lenthall E≈øquire, Speaker of the Parliament of England.
div.p: WHen his Excellency marched from Dublin towards Mun≈øter, he left me intru≈øted with that Garri≈øon, my ≈øelfe, and tho≈øe left with me at that time being ≈øicke: The fir≈øt party that recovered were ≈øent after the Army; to wit, about 800 Foot, and 200 Hor≈øe, which fought and beat the Enemy upon their march: Some more of tho≈øe ≈øicke men that were left recovering, and ≈øome recruits comming over. After I had ≈øurpri≈øed the ≈øtrong Fort upon the Bog of Allin, and taken Ca≈øtle-Martin in the County of Kildare, and placed a Garri≈øon therein. About the latter end of December, marched with a party of 1000 Hor≈øe and Foot into the I≈øland of Allin, and ≈øummoned Killmaog therein, but finding it not feazable to ≈øtorme without Guns, I marched to Rabride and Pon≈øers Grange, and tooke them, and placed two ≈øtrong Garri≈øons there, which did give me good footing in the County of Kildare, then ≈øent a party and took Kildare, Hertwell, and Cotling≈øtowne, three u≈øefull Garri≈øons in the ≈øaid County; and provi≈øions being ≈øpent returned back to Dublin, there endeavouring to get Guns, Mortar peeces, and other nece≈ø≈øaries ready to draw forth againe with all po≈ø≈øible ≈øpeed; in the interim I received Propo≈øitions from the Governour and Officers in the ≈øtrong Garri≈øon and Fort of Balli≈øonan, the originall whereof, I here inclo≈øed pre≈øent you with all under their owne hands, which being by me utterly rejected.

I marched upon Tue≈øday the 26 of Feb. with a party of 2000 Foot, and 1000 Hor≈øe, towards the County of Kildare, and took with me one Culverin, and one Demi-culverin, and one Mortar-piece, the Enemy fired their Garri≈øons of Fort of Lea≈øe, Blackreath, & the forementioned Ca≈øtle of Kilmaog in the I≈øland of Allin; but I ≈øhall ea≈øily make it tenable againe, it being very u≈øefull for your ≈øervice, they al≈øo did blow up the Ca≈øtle of Athy, where they had a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon, and broke up the Bridge. Upon the 28 Feb. I marched from the Naas, and about four a clock with the Van of the party, I came to Belli≈øonan a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon, double Works, and double moted, full of water one within another, and amount with a Fort upon it, mo≈øt of the Officers with me e≈øteeming the taking of it to be unfeazable, it being late, and I unwilling to lo≈øe time, did ≈øend in a Summons, a copy whereof is here inclo≈øed, & the inclo≈øed an≈øwer under the Governours hand was pre≈øently returned, & the Town which was without his Works by him burned that night, I cau≈øed a Battery to be made and planted the Artillery, and made a Fort for the ≈øecurity therof, having intelligence that the Lord of Ca≈øtlehaven, with 4000
Hor≈øe and Foot would come to rai≈øe me within two dayes, in which Fort I could ≈øecure the Guns and batter their Works, w ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to fight the Enemy if need were, we played our Guns and Morter-peece at the Fort upon the Mount, intending before night to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ orme it, having Ladders, and all nece≈ø≈øaries ready, but before any breach was made, the Governour did ≈øend me a paper which is here inclo≈øed, whereunto the inclo≈øed an≈øwer was returned, and he treated with me about the ≈øurrender, which was concluded accordingly. The Articles ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with both our hands herewith, is repre≈øented unto you.

And now Sir, you have without the lo≈ø≈øe of one man this ≈øtrong place, and thereby mo≈øt of the County of Kildare; tho≈øe Garri≈øon ‚Ä¢ in this County yet remaining, as Ca≈øtle Dormount, and Kilkenny, with others, I hope you ≈øhall have a good account thereof ≈øpeedily from,

I Am now marching the Army to reduce that place you po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe unto the obedience of the Parliament of England, and it being apparent to the world that God is making inqui≈øition in Ireland for innocent blood, how farre you and tho≈øe with you may be concerned therein, I ≈øhall ob≈øerve by your An≈øwer hereunto.

The≈øe are to require you to deliver that place you now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, unto me for the end afore≈øaid: what≈øoever your return hereunto may be and the effect thereof, my Summons will ju≈øtifie the future proceedings of

I Am now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in this place by authority from my King, how you may demand it by authority from the Parliament of England, I know not: England denying their King, therefore your power I di≈øobey: And for God, my King, and Country, will defend this place to the uttermo≈øt of my power,
div.trailer:
For Col. Hew≈øon Commander in chiefe of the Parliament party now at the Field of
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lli≈øanon.

div.head: Propo≈øitions made by the Gari≈øon, which were rejected.
div.p: VVE doe hereby employ Governour Donno O Kelly, for the delivery of the hereunder Propo≈øitions to the Commi≈øsioners Generall of the Parliaments Forces of Ireland.

list.item: Imprimis, That the party commanding this Gari≈øon and Fort of Balli≈øonan, and all other that will adhere to them are really and willingly to joyne to the Parliament Forces, upon ≈øuch termes as are hereunder written.

2 That a Collonel, Lieutenant Collonel, and a Major be≈øides Captaines, and under officers, he imployed of the ≈øaid party, con≈øtantly in the ≈øtanding Army, of the Parliaments Forces of this Kingdome; That in ca≈øe any ≈øuch officers come in,
3 That they may have free liberty of their Religion and t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Prie≈øts admitted and imployed for to ≈øerve the ≈øaid Regiment now intended.
4 That neither Taaffe, nor Dillon ≈øhall be accepted of in the Parliaments party.
5 That their e≈øtates wrongfully detained and enjoyed by the ≈øaid Dillon, Bourne and Taaffes, may be allowed unto them by the ≈øtat ‚Ä¢ of Parliament,

6 That their Arrears ≈øince May la≈øt, may be allowed them, this and the afore≈øaid Propo≈øitions may be granted by the Generall, Lieutenant Generall, Major Generall, and Commi≈øsioners generall of the Parliament Forces of this Kingdom ‚Ä¢ , that what tho≈øe Counties a≈ø≈øigned to them for their pay, are in Arreare ≈øince their comming to Balli≈øonan, may be forthwith cau≈øed to be paid.
7 That this granted they ≈øhall obey any deriving power from the State of Parliament.

div.p:
BLood I doe not thir≈øt after, yet ≈øo far a Souldier, as not to neglect pre≈øent opportunity, I ≈øhall for the end in your Letter mentioned, ≈øend Captaine Hew≈øon according to your de≈øire, provided you ≈øend one or two fully Authori≈øed to treat and conclude, and all to be concluded within halfe an houre, provided al≈øo you doe not worke at all to repaire what my Guns, and Morter peece have demoli≈øhed; and to that
end that Cap. Hew≈øon may rem ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ e in the Mount duri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ that halfe houre. Sir, I ≈øhall be glad if your wi≈ødome prevent what ot ‚Ä¢ er ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ avoidably will fall out, though not de≈øired by.

TO avoyd the confu≈øion of Chri≈øtian blood we ≈øent out a Drum ‚Ä¢ o demand a Parley, my de≈øire for the rea≈øons afor ‚Ä¢ ≈øaid is, th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yo ‚Ä¢ ≈øend in a Captaine of your ‚Ä¢ to tr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t with us, and we will ≈øend forth a Captaine of ours, who ≈øhall demand no more but what is honourable and ju≈øt, and ≈øo Sir, I conclude;

div.head: Articles agreed upon: between the Honourable Col. John Hew≈øon of the one Part, and Captain Donno ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Kelly Go ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t of Belli≈øanon in the County of Kildare of the other part. 1 March, 1649.

list.item: IMprimis, That the ≈øaid Garri≈øon and Fort of Belli≈øonan, ≈øhall bee immediately delivered with all the A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nition, a ‚Ä¢ d „Äà‚óä„Äâ therein, except as in the in≈øuing Article is agreed upon

2 That the ≈øaid Governour Officers and Souldiers, ≈øhall detaine in the Ca≈øtle untill to morrow morning at ten of the clocke if they plea≈øe and then they are to march out of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle and Fort with a Tr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
peter for Convoy Tenne miles if they de≈øire „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ next Iri≈øh Garri≈øons within ten miles „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ld, the Tr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pet ‚Ä¢ r returning without any prejudice. And the ≈øaid Officers are „Äà‚óä‚óä„Äâ with their Hor≈øes and Pi≈øtolls, and with their Colours flying and Drums beating, and the Souldiers with their Ar ‚Ä¶ and Muske ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lighted, and each Musketeer one pound of powder with Bullet and Match proportionable.
3 What≈øoever Oates and Pea≈øe ≈øhall ‚Ä¢ pp ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r to be in the Ca≈øtle belonging to Mis. Fitz Gerald ≈øhall be re≈øtored to her
And la≈øtly, for the due performing of the afore≈øaid Articles, doe hereunto ≈øet our Hands the day and yeare fir≈øt above written‚ñ™

div.head: For the right Honourable William Lenthall E≈øquire, Speaker in the Parliament of England,
div.p: UPon the ≈øixth in≈øtant, (information being given that five Companies of the Enemies Foot were come to Poores Court about eight miles from hence, on Wickloe ≈øide) a Party was ≈øent from this place under the command of Sir Theophilus Iones to beat them our, or fight them, but before our Party got thither they demoli≈øht all the buildings, they pull'd down the very walls, and fled away into the woods; we cannot keep any Garri≈øon there, becau≈øe there is no manner of ≈øhelter for our men there.
The tenth in≈øtant, Letters from Sir Charles Coote (then at Belfa≈øt) brought the newes of reducing Ca≈øtle Dooe.
There was lately a generall Coun≈øell of the Clergy at Kilkenny, who treated upon Propo≈øitions pre≈øented among≈øt them≈øelves for carrying on of the War.

The Plague continues in Galway, where there hath neare twenty thou≈øand dyed ≈øince, the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt la≈øt; mo≈øt of their Gentry there have peri≈øht by it, among the re≈øt Ieffery Browne, heretofore a Practi≈øer at Law in England, Sir Richard Blague, both prime actors, and chiefe in the ≈øupreame Coun≈øell, with many others of their mo≈øt eminent contrivers of the Rebellion are dead.
Ormond was lately at Portumny with the Earle of Clanrickard in Conaught.

On Wedne≈øday la≈øt, Captaine Molineux arrived here from Wexford, who brings the newes of our taking the Fort of Bally-haoke, over again≈øt Pa≈ø≈øage upon the River of Waterford, ≈øo that all trading by Sea to Waterford is wholly ≈øtopt up; be≈øides, there is a very great feare and jealou≈øie, between the Towne≈ø-men of Waterford, and the Souldiers there who are of the Northerne Iri≈øh.

We have certaine newes from Mun≈øter, that my Lord Lievtenant hath been in the Field this good while, and hath taken Ca≈øhell and Callan (the latter being within ≈øix miles of Kilkenny) with ≈øeverall other con≈øiderable Garri≈øons of the Rebbels about tho≈øe parts, and now about if not in Clonmell.
The Plague is very hot in Kilkenny.
The Toryes have behaved themselves ≈øo barbarou≈øly towards tho≈øe of their owne Party, that the Fryers and Prie≈øts have excommunicated them.

The Governour on Tue≈øday la≈øt marcht into the County of Kildare, and we hourely expect an accompt of the reducing of ≈øeverall con≈øiderable Garri≈øons thereabout; great Guns are this day ≈øent from hence unto him, the extreame wants of accommodations of all kinds for our men will I feare weaken our Army, and impede the pre≈øent carrying,
on of the ≈øervice in the neglect of this opportunity now the ‚Ä¢ nemy is di≈øper≈øt and di≈øtracted, and a ≈ømall matter will now effect that which a farre greater will not hereafter; I have not el≈øe to trouble your Honour, but humbly crave leave to re≈øt, Sir;

closer.signed: Your Honours mo≈øt humble Servant William Baft.

div.head: For the Honourable William Lenthall E≈øquire, Speaker in the Parlia ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of England.
div.p:
IT hath plea≈øed God exceedingly to ble≈ø≈øe our Forces in th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ce, in their late march into the County of Kildare, where they have t ‚Ä¢ ken in the Fort and Ca≈øtle of Belle≈øonan by ≈øurrender, ≈øuprized Athy, being a Pa≈ø≈øe upon the Barrow, and a place of very great concernment, both for the enlarging of our Quarters, inve≈øting the enemy, and ≈øecuring a pa≈ø≈øe to joyne with my Lord if occa≈øion require. In all which t ‚Ä¢ e Go ‚Ä¢ erno ‚Ä¢ r hath placed Garri≈øons; as al≈øo in K ‚Ä¶ e being the Ca≈øtle of the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of Allen, which the enemy had burnt and indeavoured to have ‚Ä¶ ed, upon the rumour of his advance from hence; but the workes are now rep ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
red and made tenable by ours.

Upon Saturday la≈øt he returned againe hither to Du ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
havin ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Forces in the outquarters about the Na ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , but intends anot ‚Ä¢ er ≈øpeedy m ‚Ä¢ rch if accommodations may be by any meanes provided.

Our Forces about Wexford have recovered the Ca≈øtle of I ‚Ä¶
which was yeelded unto them, And have taken Brown-wooll by Mort ‚Ä¢ r‚ñ™
‚Ä¢ ll within the latter were put to the ≈øword.
Col: Treavour hath by expre≈ø≈øe ≈øent his re≈øolution to ‚Ä¶ t the „Äà‚óä„Äâ and hath leave from the Governour to come into our Quarters, an ‚Ä¢ to ≈øtay untill my Lords plea≈øure be further known.
I have not el≈øe to trouble your Honour but humbly rema ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e,

Your Honours ‚Ä¢ ost „Äà‚óä„Äâ S ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
